text: MAGGIE: We see the back of her blonde head. It’s a beauti winter day. Now we see her from across the street. We see feet making determined strides. This is a young woman who knows where she is going. Wide shot: A blind man is tentatively making ready to cro the street. Among the handful of pedestrians about to cross, Maggie i the only one to notice, and helps the man across.

TONY, Maggie’s best friend, looks a little like Art Garfu as a young man: fluffy hair, glasses, dressed in a suit jacket and baggy chinos. He’s pushing a stroller with a reading, fluffy-haired, bespectacled four year old boy in wearing a t-shirt with “IMAGINE THERE’S NO FRACKING” writ on the front. This boy is too big to be in a stroller, an too young to be reading. Maggie rushes to them.
Sorry! Sorry I’m late... Hi! Hi Max! She snuffles the little boy’s neck.
You still have one little corner of baby smell. Right (sniff) there. Max giggles and pushes her away so he can get back to his reading. Maggie straightens up.
Ach, I need a baby! She bites her fist.
You need a baby? You’re such an impatient little fuss-budget.
I just don’t see why I should wait.
For a father, perhaps? (CONTINUED)
Let’s face it. I’ve never been in a serious relationship that lasted longer than six months.
(paying) We were together for two years. They walk.
In college. And we made each other miserable for the rest of the time.
I admit it. We were miserable. But we were also happy.
Yeah. They reach a stand of homemade jams. Tony picks one up.
Just so you know. I have little sperm tucked away in a facility uptown, if you’re in a pinch.
What?! Why? I thought Felicia didn’t want any more kids.
Felicia does not want any more kids. I froze it in case I ever meet anybody nice.
No, you didn’t.
I didn’t. But I might, you know, save it, like ‘mad money’-style? Maggie has something to tell Tony, and she wants to get i over with fast.
(rushing this part) Do you remember Guy Childers, from college? (CONTINUED)
A moment as Tony searches for the name in his mind.
Wasn’t he the Guy...he’s a pickle salesman?
He’s a pickle entrepreneur. And-- he’s agreed to make a donation, so I can inseminate myself.
But he has no sense of personal space!
So what? He was a math major. Anyway, I’m not marrying him, I’m borrowing his genes.
But not his personality I hope. Guy Childers...?
(shrugs ) Everybody has something a little wrong with them. You think everybody's honest who fills out those questionnaires at the sperm bank?
I can’t believe you've been cooking this up all this time and you didn’t even tell me.
I knew that you’d yell at me.
I’m not yelling at you! Isn’t this sort of thing for women who are like forty-nine and desperate?
I don’t want it to be a last resort, I want it to be a choice. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

Because I’m ready be a mother, and I don’t believe I’1l find a man who I can stay in love with-- or who can stay in love with me-- for more than six months. I’m just facing the truth about myself. Tony is morose at this news, but he accepts it.
So when’s the insemination? Are we gonna have a party?
In four months. As they walk away from camera:
Do I have bad breath? He breaths into the air near her mouth. She sniffs.
No. Do I? She breathes into his mouth.

No. And they walk off. Good friends; unusual friends... INT. GUY CHILDERS’ BROOKLYN PICKLE FACTORY - DAY 8 Hipsters in hats and Mexican technicians are creating pic in huge vats. GUY is walking Maggie through aisle after a of pickles. Guy is wearing a Peruvian hat with flaps, sho and clogs.

I started production in my apartment three years ago. Now I have twelve employees, and I just got an order from Whole Foods. If that works out we’re taking off. But I’m still very hands on. Every pickle has my stamp of approval on it. He withdraws a pickle from a vat. (CONTINUED)
Here, try this one.
I love this!
That’s the Bavarian. Classic.
This is the best pickle I’ve ever had. Guy looks at her, beaming. Jump cut:
Guy and Maggie are at the front desk of Brooklyn Brine. G takes off his gloves as Maggie notices a pair of hockey skates hanging from a coat stand.
You skate?
Every Sunday. I grew up on the ice.
Oh right. You were on the ice hockey team.
Yeah.
I used to skate a lot when I was little. A moment of awkwardness.
So, regarding our plan. Here... is my bill of health. With an air of pride, he spreads his blood test results across the desk.
Read it. (CONTINUED)
(scanning the results) That’s great.
Oh! I have for you: Maggie takes an empty plastic specimen jar out of her pur
Ah. He takes it and looks into it, as if for an answer.
You need to keep it warm, when you...so just put it next to your body underneath your shirt...and you can come right over.
Okay... Guy places the jar on the desk. They look at it together.
So when do you want to do this?
March...twenty third? Guy thinks about his schedule. No conflicts come to mind.
I just want to build up some more savings. Guy pulls out a stool for Maggie solicitously, in anticipation, perhaps, of her pregnancy.
That’s smart.
I have insurance and everything. So, I guess the question is, how much involvement do you want? I was going to suggest none, but I’m open to negotiation. A beat as Guy digests this. (CONTINUED)
None is...so cool. It kind of takes the pressure off, doesn’t it? He takes a seat and leans back against the refrigerator, beside a large circulating fan.

I can just relax, and build my empire. The fan blows Guy’s STD bloodtest result paper across his desk; they both move to stop it, and their fingers touch. INT. MAGGIE’S BUILDING - DAY 3 Close up of a mailbox being opened with a key. Maggie draws out two identical white envelopes. Puzzled, opens one, then the other. EXT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - DAY A3 Maggie walks outside.
Maggie enters the big glass doors. INT. NEW SCHOOL - BURSAR’S OFFICE - DAY 5 A large woman with close-cropped hair and a neck brace si behind the desk with the air of a sage.
Hi Beverly. I got two checks this month. Not that I’m complaining.
You sure they’re not for two different payments?
I would love to think that... but they have the same date on them and I was paid last month.
Excuse me... (CONTINUED)
The camera pans right to include a shambolic, sleep-depri edgy man.
I couldn't help but overhear this young woman got two checks. And I don’t have any. Beverly looks up at him, displeased at this complication.
What’s your name?
John Harding.

Oh well my name is Johanna Hardin, I mean my name is Maggie... but on the check it’s Johanna Margaret Hardin. So maybe there was a mix- up. Beverly is on the computer. She looks a little put out. S hates this kind of thing.
Yep. And it’s gonna take a minute to figure this out.
It would be great if it could be resolved soon. Beverly looks up at him with her final answer.
We'll get back to you.
Maggie and John walk down the hallway.
Damn. That woman could guard hell, if Cerberus ever needs to go to the vet.
Everyone’s scared of Beverly. What do you teach? (CONTINUED)
Ficto-critical Perspectives in Family Dynamics, and Masks in the Modern Family, Victorian Times to the present day.
Psychology department?
Anthropology.
(scrutinizing him) I don’t know any anthropologists.
What about you?
I’m the Director of Business Development and Outreach for the art and design students.
What’s that?
I help graduate students strategize for success in the art and design world. Sort of a bridge between art and commerce. I help them sell their souls. And eat.
Are you old enough to do that job?

I have a master’s degree in arts management. They exit frame as the camera, with a will of its own, pa down to look through the glass wall at the courtyard belo and a round metal bench with a phallic center.
(os) Good to know. See you later.
(os) Good luck with getting paid!  10 10.

Several days later, Maggie is in line with FELICIA, Tony' wife. Felicia is wearing a t-shirt with “What would Jesus Buy?” Written on it. She and Felicia are mid-conversation when John calls out. The camera pans over to him.
Felicia -- when is that -- that Pike fellowship meeting?
Thursday at seven.
(sighing) Great, thanks. The women sit.
That’s so funny that you know John Harding.
(eating her soup) We're on a committee together. He’s a real panty melter. Why?
No, we just -- had a check mix-up recently -- because of our names-- Hardin/Harding.
He’s one of the bad-boys of Ficto- critical Anthropology. Apparently, he was a big deal in Chicago. And now he just does adjunct work here, but they’re really salivating for him to teach full-time.
Why won’t he?
I don’t know. I think it has something to do with his wife. She’s some kind of monster apparently.
Where did you hear this? (CONTINUED)

(shrugging) Around. She’s got tenure at Columbia. Georgette Nergaard. The words ‘Glacial’ and ‘Terrifying’ have been bandied about. Then again I've heard myself described as a psychotic bitch, but I think I’m actually pretty nice, so... you can’t believe everything you hear. Maggie is distracted by John’s voice.
-if you say ‘she was, like, terrified’, it’s nothing compared to saying’ she was terrified’. "Like” is a language condom. Trust me. Maggie looks back at John, now a far more mysterious character.
(searching in her salad) Where the fuck is my chicken?
John is nursing a coffee, sitting on a bench, reading the paper, when he notices Maggie, who is circling the founta with vigorous, calisthenic strides. He watches her circle couple times. Calls out:
Hey, Hardin?
Oh, hi!
What are you doing?
I'm taking a little constitutional before my next meeting. John gets up and walks over to her.
Did you get paid yet? (CONTINUED)
No.
You're kidding.
Beverly tells me the check is coming any day now. 12. 11 Maggie and John walk past a man in a fancy suit kneeling scoop up his dog’s turd.

I knew this Masai from Tanzania. He was here to run in the Marathon. He took everything in New York City in complete stride. Nothing fazed him until he saw a grown man following his dog, picking up its shit. He started laughing so hard, he wept.
I guess that-- custom-- would be strange, like, out of context. Whoops!
What?
I overheard part of your conversation. About ‘like’ being a - - language prophylactic. He’s trying to remember saying that.
What is ficto-critical anthropology, anyway?
It’s a way of writing about anthropology that blends ethnographic observation, story telling and, like, theory. A beat. Two smiles. (CONTINUED)
Do we have to walk in a circle, or are we allowed walk around the park?
We're allowed. They begin to meander.
(curious about him) It’s so hard to find a full-time position.

When my wife, Georgette, was offered a tenured position at Columbia, I decided to put off a job search, just teach a few classes and finally try to write this novel I’ve had in my head for years. They pass two bomb squad-looking men sharing a joke. They walk
(intrigued) So, are you getting a lot of work done, on your novel?
They say every relationship has a gardener, and a rose. Georgette is definitely the rose.
And you’re the gardener.
And I don’t have a green thumb.
Maybe you’re a rose in disguise.
It would be a very good disguise. along for a moment.
She's wonderful. It’s just she’s kind of destroying my life. (CONTINUED)
Maggie isn’t sure how to respond to this remark, dropped kind of aside as John ambles along.
No, no. It’s just been a bad week. (looking up at the sky) It’s turning into a beautiful day. They come to a man performing Shakespearean soliloquies f donations.

Content with Hermia? No! I do repent/The tedious minutes I with her have spent. Not Hermia, but Helena I love./Who would not change a raven for a dove? John gives him a dollar. ACTOR (CONT’D) Thanks, man.
A few minutes later. They have cupcakes and are sitting o the same bench John was on earlier. They are mid- conversation.
We have two of those. Best part of my life. Who’s your guy?
No guy. Actually, the man I’ve asked to be the father is named Guy, coincidentally. John tears a bite off.
(laughing) You eat like Mr. Fox!
(CONTINUED)
There was a Roald Dahl book? And then it was a movie--
Oh yeah. My kids loved that movie. Maggie looks at her watch.
I really like what you're doing, though--having a baby by yourself. Not that it won’t be hard, because it’s gonna be fucking hard. But, I admire your courage. And I love babies.
I just don’t like leaving my destiny...
To destiny?
Right. The Shakespearean actor from the park walks by them, stil his ruff. He is with another man who is silent, furious.
(tearful) But where will I go? The other man shrugs. The Actor runs after his lover. ACTOR (CONT’D) You can’t just kick me out of our house...
(to Maggie) I have a question for you.
Yes?
Would you consider reading a chapter of my novel?
Sure. (CONTINUED)
I know that’s weird. I really want the first reader to be like...You know how you said you're a bridge between art and commerce? Well, I need a bridge.
Perfect. Give it to me. I’ll read it. John reaches into his backpack and pulls out about fifty pages of a novel.
You really will? I really would appreciate it. Maggie takes it.
I don’t mind at all. She looks at her watch.
I gotta go. Shoot. John looks at his watch.
(panicked) Oh shit! Shit! Shit! I gotta go. I gotta go!
Oh-- He grabs his bag and runs off.
I’1ll see you later. Thank you!
(baffled, calling after him) Okay, Bye!
John rushes to the wings and into a big close up as he lo out at the stage with trepidation. (CONTINUED)
(under his breath) Fuck.

(os) What do you make of the use of masks in the Occupy movement? High shot: see John stride onto the stage. GEORGETTE, Joh beautiful Danish wife, and a moderator, KLIEGLER, have started this panel on MASKS IN POLITICS without him. His is rudely empty. As John does his walk of shame across th stage, Georgette speaks in a clipped Danish accent.

The masked revolutionary is a direct inversion of the face of the demagogue-- the essentially fascist ideal of the magnetic individual... As John passes, Georgette gives him an extremely dirty lo Laughter, laughing. Applause.
(into the mic) Sorry I’m late. because he’s so damn charismatic. Georgette isn’t
(holding up John’s book) John Harding, author of many books, most recently, “Rituals of Commodity Fetishism at the Tail End of the Empire”. He’s popular.
So John, of course we have been discussing the Occupy movement--
I can’t help mentioning the irony that Warner Brothers owns the copyright on the V for Vendetta mask that became the face of the Occupy movement. (CONTINUED)
Applause. 18.
Like it or not, in this country, the most potent, totemic symbols are cinematic or television-based; so it only makes sense that a radical, popular movement would try to subvert them.
Nevertheless, the reality of Occupy is to be found within the capitalist narrative, as a kind of subplot.
This sweeping cynicism of yours--
If by sweeping cynicism you mean not living in a dream, then shoot me now.
Maybe the way we--
Nobody ever thinks a revolution is going to happen until three days after it’s happened. This was a leaderless movement. It wasn’t going to happen on a schedule. This was a genuine populist uprising.
Yes! Because-—

Absolutely. But to return to the use of masks in politics. I am more interested in the possibility of anonymity and group affiliation -- the “I am Spartacus” maneuver -- which has been the primary tactical explanation of the use of masks among various 20th and 21st century protest movements. Including the Zapatistas, the black blocs of the anti-globalization movement, and, of course, Pussy Riot. (CONTINUED)
As her speech wears on, we see John wilting like a daisy sauna. He radiates resentment and defeat.
INT. JOHN AND GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT - EVENING 16 Close up of Georgette’s manicured hand, texting. We go wi to reveal a family dinner. John is standing, serving Georgette pasta.
You don’t need to help, but could you please put that down?
(texting) One moment. She puts the phone down. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Okay. John sits. JUSTINE, 13, in a school uniform, sits beside dreamy brother, PAUL, 7.
I don’t get why you say the same thing in the concluding paragraph as you do in the opening paragraph.
You're repeating your thesis but in a more developed form.
What’s the point of that?
By the time you get to the conclusion you’ve proven your thesis.
So it’s basically just gloating.
(amused) It is a form of gloating, yes. (CONTINUED)
(To John: ) They have fleas in Paul’s class again.
They don’t have fleas. They have lice.
Okay, lice.
(to Paul) Let me check your head. Paul walks over to John. John checks his head.
You don’t have lice. Georgette catches Justine texting.
No texting at the table.
I wonder where she gets it.
I use my phone for work.
Sometimes I’d like to smash it with a hammer.
Ha-ha. Georgette’s phone rings. She is dying to answer. The kids both watch their mother restrain herself as John fumes. T phone rings out as Justine speaks.
Way to go Mom.
Salad? As Georgette serves, her phone pings: a text! She glances the text and sucks in air, shocked. (CONTINUED)
What is it?
(flushed with excitement) They've asked me to chair the department at Columbia!
Congratulations. That’s great.
It'd be a huge time commitment.
Still, it’s a high-class problem.

When will I ever get my writing done? I’ve promised to deliver that book by December. Georgette checks her reddening breast bone. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Come on. You'll get a big bump in salary-- GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Look -- I’m already breaking out in a rash!
I’ve got an idea. Why don’t you call Caleb back and discuss it.
I have to.
Justine, you want to text your friend. Justine nods, mystified by this change in policy.
Paul, you want to play Ninja Revinja on your iPad? Go. 21. 16 Paul jumps up to get the iPad. John pulls out a flip phon (CONTINUED)

I myself even have a minor text I would like to respond to. We can skip the pretence of having a close- knit family dinner. (looking down at his phone) And we can return to the bullshit later. Justine texts. Georgette is on the phone. Close on his te from Maggie: “finished the first chapter!”
(os) What is it?
Close on John’s manuscript.
The tone is so unusual - sort of screwball-surreal. Is that right?
That sounds right. Screwball- surreal. That’s it exactly! They are both freezing, huddled on their bench.
And oh my God the characters! Martin Neems the colorless postal worker in 1950’s Connecticut and he’s married to this crazy Brazilian woman who keeps breaking out in rashes! It’s hilarious.
(drinking in her praise) Really? Really?
Oh, and the description of the musical collection!
Oh, yeah, his records you mean?
Yes. Oh, that is so great. (CONTINUED)
It’s funny, right?

Oh, it’s great. I’m sorry. I am very, very cold. I feel like I’m welded to the bench. Is it okay if we go get some coffee? The camera moves left, to a westward path, as if it knows what’s going to happen next. MAGGIE (CONT’D) (os) Actually, my apartment is like three blocks from here. I just need to get another sweater. I’m deathly cold. They walk into shot and walk down the path through the fr wind.
I cannot tell you how much I appreciate you doing this.
Oh it was so much fun to read.
Really? Did you think the boil was gross or funny?
INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - AFTERNOON 19 Maggie and John enter, gasping with cold. The tiny living room is absolutely crammed with books.
I sublet from a poet. John looks around him at this charming apartment.
You want some tea? Or...I guess that’s his wine, or...I have whiskey. It’s a little early. (CONTINUED)
We could make a hot whiskey. Do you have some honey and lemon? Maggie looks into the fridge.
I have half a lemon. And... honey.
I‘1l make it for you. Maggie walks to her closet and puts away her coat.
Okay, great.
(os) You're clearly a reader.
Actually most of these books are his. Maggie looks in the mirror for a moment.
INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - AFTERNOON 20 Close on a pair of glass mugs filled with hot whiskey.
Hot whiskey.
Oh, thank you. She takes a sip.
Oh it’s so good. Medium wide: they sit in silence for a moment.
So. Tell me. I’m curious about you. Maggie looks up at him. (CONTINUED)
He stands, 25. 20
What about me? What aspect of me?
Every aspect.
I don’t know where to start.
How about the beginning? takes off his jacket.
I’m hot.
Oh, I know. John sits down again.
(drinks) Well, I had a... kind of unusual start.
wee?

My parents were married fairly young and they never had kids. They were academics at the University of Wisconsin. Then eventually they got divorced, my Dad moved away... but then later, years later, they ran into each other at a party. And they... they got together that night. And that’s how I was conceived. On the bed with all the coats. My mom always says that it’s because I needed to be born.
I love that idea. That our unborn children are the real gods, dictating the fates of us poor, clueless mortals. Did they...they got together after that? (CONTINUED)
Saying it Maggie is 26.

No. My mother raised me on her own in Madison. She was a professor of nineteenth century British poetry. She wasn't very practical. So I ended up doing all the day-to-day stuff. I was organizing the bills by the time I was twelve. She came from a Quaker family... so she used to take me to Quaker meetings with her. I still go, sometimes.
A Quaker.
We had a nice life. And then when I was sixteen, she died. still shocks Maggie, and tears glimmer in her eyes.
(matter of fact) So I moved in with my Dad in Philly. surprised to feel that she’s crying.
How was that?
Um... cordial. And quiet.
Sounds lonely.
Yes. He finds her so touching.
I grew up in a house... where nobody ever stopped yelling at each other.
(recovering, laughing) Heaven! (CONTINUED)
A moment. He stands 27.
(trying to be positive) My dad is a kind man. And he made the best of it. We both did. The atmosphere has changed.
So what about you? Tell me about you. Background-wise.

My father worked at a blackjack table in Atlantic City. But it’s a really long story. And I have to get back to my dysfunction. back up. Puts on his coat. Looks down at her sitting on the couch. He rushes
I believe it.
What?

That you had to be born. out the door. As it shuts, the ‘reading, writing, falling in love’ montage (improvised dialogue) begins: INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - DAY Maggie reads John’s book. This image is intercut with:
& GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT - DAY OR NIGHT B22 John writing at his dining room table. (We hear his voice over the montage.)
Martin Neem dreamed the same thing every night, but he could never remember what it was. His wife, Talia, slept like a stone. Talia was a small woman. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
A small, beautiful woman with hair like a river of snakes and the temper of an angry mink.

John is walking away from us; Maggie toward us. They meet the middle of the hallway, greet each other, then John tu and goes off with Maggie, toward camera. He can’t resist talking about the new chapter she just read.
Maggie skating.
John and Maggie discuss his book on their bench in Washin Square Park, eating dosai.
New School courtyard (seen from above on the round bench saw earlier): Maggie and John, still talking about the te
Do you think this is overwritten?
(OS)

I think John’s book is a novella. INT. FELICIA AND TONY’S APARTMENT - DAY C22 Maggie, looking a little tired, but lovely in a tweed ski and sweater, is eating a carrot as Tony tries to assemble piece of IKEA furniture.
It’s short and very strange. It might even be an allegory. I like everything I’ve read. He’s asking me for suggestions.
Oh? What does his wife think about that? (CONTINUED)
She doesn’t know about it. To be honest, I don’t think she pays much attention to what he does. She’s very self-absorbed. She might even be a narcissist.
Of course she is.
Why of course? He’s basically a psychiatric nurse. He can’t write his novel under those conditions -- I think their marriage fell apart after the second child was born. And now he’s trapped in it.
That's what he’s telling you.
Why would he lie?

To get in your pants! INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - LATE AFTERNOON 24 It’s March twenty-third. Guy is taking off his jacket. Ma looks to see if the pockets are bulging. He reaches into large pocket and produces a small, mashed bouquet.
Oh! Thank you. She puts the flowers in a glass, then turns expectantly.
Did you... bring it?
Oh! Fuck... I’m sorry.
That's why I gave you the little... container?
Where’s your bathroom? (CONTINUED)
Um... Guy looks around the room.
So what do I deposit my genetic gold mine into? Maggie rushes over to her cupboard and takes out a little plastic jar like the first one she gave him.
(handing it to him) It’s sterile. Guy holds it between his thumb and forefinger. He takes a step to the bathroom, then turns back.

Listen. I feel it behooves me, to, ah, offer to do this the old fashioned way. Given the extreme state of your beauty and my totally free afternoon. A moment as the absolute awkwardness of this offer sinks
No...no thank you, Guy. I just think that would be too complicated.
No sweat, just being polite.
Should I go out for a while?
Nah, just read something. I'll be back in a jiff with the jizz. He marches to the bathroom.
Guy?
Hm? (CONTINUED)
Why didn’t you end up becoming a mathematician?
I liked math because it was beautiful, that’s all. I never wanted to be a mathematician.
(encouraged) Really? You think math is beautiful?
I don’t think. I know. Anyone who has touched even a hem of that garment knows it’s beautiful. For me, the hem was enough. I couldn’t have taken the frustration.
What do you mean?

Of never seeing the whole thing. Of always just getting little glimpses of the whole picture. Spending my whole life hunting for scraps of truth. Embarrassed by his own candor, Guy turns and shuts the do to the bathroom, leaving Maggie bemused and oddly charmed this unique character. Hearing the water run in the bathr she turns some Ska music up high on the iPod as a sound buffer. She is so happy, she does a solitary dance. After few beats, Guy appears with the plastic jar Maggie gave h a little cloudy something at the bottom. He watches her d for a moment. We can see how much he likes her. Seeing hi Maggie stops dancing, embarrassed.
Wow. Swift. She tries to take the jar, but Guy swoops it away from he and washes it off in the kitchen sink, then swaddles it i tea towel like a newborn.
Of course when there’s an actual lady involved, it’s a different story. I made you extra...just in case you spill some. (CONTINUED)
He hands her the bundle gently, as if it were already a b
Thank you, Guy. This is really great.
Super. He just stands there. Now what? He fishes his phone out o his pocket and turns the lens on himself, Maggie, and the container, which he gets her to hold up. Maggie is embarrassed and confused.
Selfie. Click! INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - BATHROOM - NIGHT 25 Insert close up: Maggie, wearing blue surgical gloves, fi a plastic syringe with Guy’s sperm.

INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - BATHROOM —- LATER 26 Maggie has a thermometer in her mouth, syringe in one han She takes out the thermometer, reads her temperature, the punches the number into her phone. A voice calls out of t phone: “you have a: seventy-one percent chance of being fertile right now”. The phone rings. Maggie puts it on speaker phone. INT. TONY AND FELICIA’S KITCHEN - INTERCUT 27
Did you do it yet?
My apps are giving me contradictory information. Maybe I should wait.
I would wait. For like five years.
Let me talk to Felicia. (CONTINUED)
Felicia takes the phone.
Don’t listen to him. He’s losing his mind.
(Os) Yeah, he seems a little on edge.
You think so? He’s driving me crazy with theories of mental illness in Guy Childers’ family.
(in BG, grating parmesan) I met his mother once. She had a face like a hatchet and she never stopped sighing. And she DRANK.
Tony just loves you too much. He wants to keep you for himself.
What are you talking about? You know that’s not true.
He doesn’t want you to move on to the next step in your life because then he, too, might actually have to grow up.
(from back of the kitchen) Will you shut the fuck up? Felicia smiles, giving Tony a semi-jovial middle finger.
(thermometer in her mouth) How high does your temperature have to be?
I think just slightly elevated.
Are you talking about the temperature? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
(yelling) A hundred and one! It has to be a hundred and one degrees!
(to Tony) When was the last time you ovulated?

Johnny Harding. The waiter nods. John gestures to Maggie to follow. They follow the man down a set of stairs.
Maggie and John follow the waiter through the kitchen. A is making dumplings with lightning speed. Maggie looks at him, totally confused.

Maggie and John emerge in a room furnished only with gamb tables and a TV on the wall playing a Chinese soap opera. Chinese men and a few women are playing Mahjong, poker, a blackjack. Everyone seems to be smoking. There are only a handful of non-Chinese players. The gamblers look up at t two new outsiders as they walk by.

(to Maggie) My dad used to take me to the owner’s old place. The waiter leads them to a black jack table where he conf briefly with an older man, and then turns. John hands the waiter a role of bills, enough to be in the game. John an Maggie sit down. A hostess places two tea cups full of clear liquid on the blackjack table and the older man starts dealing. Maggie takes a sip of the liquid in the teacup and does a double take.
What’s in this? (CONTINUED)
Just drink it, ok? The dealer deals out the cards. John plays a hand.
This is for all the marbles. Maggie, who doesn’t know how to play, is watching the act rapt. John wins. It takes her a second to realize it.

We won! We won! She kisses his cheek. She’s gone through a few cups of th “tea” the hostess keeps pouring in everyone’s cup, and sh getting tipsy. She and John are flirting, having fun. The scene becomes a montage of gamblers, cards, music, drinki Maggie taps her card with a little swagger.
Is that good? Right?
No.
No? Their chips are swept away.
(laughing) No! Please no. Where did they go? They are having fun. She is served a beer, takes a slug.
Drown my sorrows.
(laughing) Slow down on that.
Maggie and John eat. John is telling a story. Maggie is having a great time. She pulls a swig of beer from the bottle.  63 64 65 69.
John and Maggie stagger up to the front desk.
We'd like a room for the night.
This is a hotel?
It is a hotel if you know it’s a hotel.
Oh-ho!
Thank you. What do I owe you? A hundred fifty dollars? I got a hundred fifty dollars. Maggie is behind John. She shoves her hands in John’s poc and fishes out some bills.
They fall into the room, laughing on the floor. John drag off Maggie's dress before he’s even closed the door. She bounds onto the bed in her slip.
Take off your clothes! She miaows like a cat, hisses, paws up.
Five! Four! Three! Two! One! He leaps on her and drags off her tights as she screams w laughter.
Take off your fucking tights! Close on her feet as she gives way to pleasure.
The next morning. John is eating breakfast; Maggie is sit in a pool of light on the bed. (CONTINUED)
(exploring-- not imploring) Would you ever want another baby?
(tossing it off) I’ll never finish the book if I don’t knuckle down and concentrate. Four kids is a lot. His reaction feels like a slap in the face.
You wouldn't notice. It’s just one more kid for you to ignore. John stops. A moment.
What kind of thing is that to say?
It’s a true thing, John. You -- I -- I’m supporting you so you can write and that’s the deal and I accept it but -- I feel like I’m your intern. Or your nanny.
For Christ’s sake. You set all this up! You took over, gave everybody a job. My job is to write my novel so that’s what I’m doing.
I know that’s what you’re doing.
You can’t get mad when we all play our parts to perfection. This stings her.
Do you even like me anymore?
What are you trying to get me to tell you? Huh? Maybe I should be asking you that question. He walks out and leaves her there.  66 67
John and Maggie walk beside each other in total alienatio
The arch reminds us of happier times between John and Mag
The phallic bench reminds us of happier times between Joh and Maggie.
Students and teachers flow in and out of the glass doors, creating liquid reflections on the glass.
Maggie is working on her computer.
May I sit down? Maggie jumps.
Sure. Georgette looks around, as if for people she knows, then sits. A moment of silence. Maggie waits for the blow.
In December, I am attending a conference in Canada on Fictocritical Anthropology.
Fictocritical Anthropology is John’s field. (CONTINUED)
I know, but -- You mean...
(cold) I’m in.
...Really?
I have no reason to trust you. On the other hand, I have absolutely nothing to lose. I could easily arrange to have John invited to give a paper at the conference.
Do you think he would accept?
Zizek is speaking. He loves Zizek. Maggie takes this in. She can’t quite believe it’s happen
Maggie is putting away dishes; John is fixing a lamp. He waits for a while to speak.
I got invited to give a paper ata conference.
Really? That’s great.
Yeah--except it’s all the way up in Quebec. So I can’t go.
No-- You have to go.
Why?
Because you... you would probably like a break. (CONTINUED)
Yeah, but Georgette’s out of town that week, too. I can’t leave you alone with all the kids.
Of course you can! I’1l be fine.
Zizek is speaking...
Oh you love Zizek!
(baffled) How do you know?
I--I think I heard you mention him.
A Canadian Airlines plane flies through a sunny sky. EXT. Quebec HOTEL - DAY 74 A stone building, rustic in aspect. A large sign reads:

head_text.subj: A WARM QUEBEC WELCOME TO THE ASSOCIATION OF FICTO-CRITICA

text: John walks into the building. Snow has begun to fall.
John walks into the dining area. A sprinkling of academic young man in a baggy sweater comes up to him.
Excuse me. John Harding?
~” (CONTINUED)
I--I’m reading “Rituals of Commodity Fetishism at the Tail End of the Empire”.
How are you making out?
It’s tremendous. We all came up here just to hear you speak. And Zizek, obviously.
Obviously.
This is a little fetish-y but-- Could you sign my book?
Sure. What’s your name?
Al. As John signs the book, he spies Georgette from behind. AL BENTWAITHE (CONT’D) Thanks!
Take care John makes his way across the room, toward Georgette.
Fancy meeting you here.
What are you doing here?
I'm giving a paper.
Did you write me you were coming here? I mean, I knew you’d be away... (CONTINUED)
I don’t know... I must have mentioned it. Are you sorry you came?
Not at all. It’s big enough for the both of us. Isn’t it? You look really well.
I feel well. Beautiful here, ya?
Yes. Great air... so far. John looks at the empty seat beside her.
Do you mind? Or should we try not to co-mingle?
It’s fine, why not? We are friends. (introducing the woman next to her) This is Debbie Wasserman. From Yale.
Hi.
Nice to meet you. After a brief, awkward smile that says she knows a lot ab John and Georgette’s divorce, Debbie turns to the dining partner on her left.
(to John) Did Maggie tell you we met?
Yes. She enjoyed meeting you.
She's an interesting person.
You think so?
Yes, very surprising. (CONTINUED)
How did you have time to be surprised?
You know how it is, we all concoct ideas of what our rival will be like. But she’s not my rival anymore.
Good.
Paul told me Maggie taught him to do a figure eight when she took him ice skating the other day. He was very proud.
She's great with him.
She seems like a very capable person.
She’s a natural mother. Georgette looks like she’s been sucker-punched. Georgette after her,
She sounds like a wonderful partner for you. I -- I need to make a phone call. I promised...
Aren’t you going to eat?

I’m not really hungry. Oh and -- maybe you’re right, it’ll be a mistake if we co-mingle too much. We'll only end up getting on each other’s nerves. leaves, angry -- at herself, mostly. John looks confused. The sound of the wind picks up.  76 77 77.

The next morning, Maggie is having a meeting with Komiko, Japanese design graduate student, and some poker-faced to executives. Komiko demonstrates her patented doll, unzipp it to reveal a string of cloth intestines.
Komiko has designed the first patented doll with removable internal organs.
(whispery) Sixty percent of children have fears about death.
Komiko’s idea is, to relieve children’s fears about the body by helping them see what’s inside.
(removing the intestine) They can draw on the organs.
But all the elements are completely washable. So...We think this would appeal to parents interested in marriage-based toys. I mean, knowledge. Knowledge-based toys.
Snow is falling on the landscape. Whirling. The wind is ferocious.
In New York, it’s two hours later. Maggie is folding laun with Justine.
(os) There’s no heat. The fucking internet doesn’t work.  78 79 78.
John, depressed, is on his phone in a corner of the bar a the end of the dining room. There is a kerosene lamp besi him. It’s still snowing. Outside, all is white. Intercut Maggie in the loft.
The generator blew up. My batteries are about to die. And get this. Guess who’s here. Georgette.
Maggie is painting Justine’s fingernails.
Really? Wow. How is that?
Her mood matches the weather.
Oh. Sorry about that.
How are you guys doing?
Everyone's fine.
I can’t get any information about when the airport is opening up. So it looks like I’m stuck here! They're breaking out the snowshoes, which, to me, is ominous.

Maggie is having a bubble bath with Lily. They are having fun, blowing bubbles through a little plastic ring. Lily the ring into the bottle of bubble stuff, blows a big one watches it float through the air.
Oh that’s a good one... (CONTINUED)
I love you so much.
How much? Wait, I know, twenty-five three hundred and sixty two!
That's exactly right! They continue to blow bubbles.
I want to live inside a bubble.
(watching the bubble float) Me too.
But I want my own bubble.
Okay. We can each have a bubble.
And Daddy gets his own bubble too. Maggie blows a huge bubble and looks inside it.
I can see Daddy in his bubble. Maggie looks inside the bubble. Slow dissolve into: A sno landscape/ John and Georgette and a few others are on snowshoes...

Low wide shot: John and Georgette walk in a line of acade on snowshoes. Georgette falls over, letting out a cry. Jo turns but she waves him off and continues. Closer frontal shot: Georgette falls again. John can’t he stopping to help her up. She dusts herself off grumpily. both look up the mountain to see the rest of the academic have trudged off without them. (CONTINUED)
Typical.
We can just follow their tracks back. They snowshoe together in silence. Time passes. 80. 80
Nothing really looks familiar. Does it? CLOSE UP OF THEIR SNOWSHOES CUTTING INTO A VIRGIN DRIFT.
They are trudging along, deep in conversation, We see them through the trees.
You know that talk you gave yesterday was just great. I didn’t even know you were working in that direction.
I guess you haven’t seen anything I’ve written for a while.
No, I miss that.
You do?
I used to like that. You know, I miss that, showing each other stuff. totally lost. (CONTINUED)
(encouraged, plunging in) Forget me -- that talk you gave yesterday was the hit of the conference.
It was just all the old ideas.
You altered that passage on de Tocqueville.
Nothing gets by you!
Your work feels so fresh... No one unpacks commodity fetishism like you do.
Aw, shucks. A few exhausting steps through the snow, walking toward c up. Then:
Are you still working on that novel?
Yeah.
How's it coming?
(brusque) Fine. He moves a little ahead. Doesn’t want to talk about it.
John.
~” (CONTINUED)
I don’t mean to be insulting about your fiction. It’s just that I am so proud of the academic work you've done. You see, here, how much people love it.
I’m not abandoning anything. Come on. I don’t want you to get too cold. Something about that little protective statement makes Georgette sad. She loves him so much. He turns.
What’s the matter?
I have something I want to tell you.
What is it?
I’m sorry.
For what?
For being so self-centered. For not listening to you, to what you needed, for not investing in your work--
Hey, you don’t have to--

I think I was just so, so tied up in succeeding, in making a name for myself, I stopped paying attention to us, to you, to our marriage. And now, I have success, and it’s as if I’ve emerged from a tunnel. I hope... in the future, to be less self-absorbed. If I ever get another chance... at love. (CONTINUED)
Of course you'll get another chance.
You think so?
I bet they’re lining up. Georgette’s eyes fill with tears. This whole thing is too much for her. She sinks down into the snow and cries.
Are we going to die here?!
No, God. (yelling) HELLO? HELLO?!
PEOPLE! WE’RE FREEZING OUT HERE AND

head_text.subj: WE HAVE NO FUCKING IDEA WHERE WE

text: John and Georgette enter, covered in snow.

(to the waiter who opens the door) We were lost. They follow the waiter who holds a torch, walking toward raucous music. A Québécois acoustic duo, a man and a woma is playing “Dancing in the Dark” by Bruce Springsteen on guitar and Harmonium on a makeshift stage. The male singe has a thick French Canadian accent. Georgette and John pl down on a couch, strip off their huge jackets, and take glasses of cognac offered to them. They sing along to “Dancing in the Dark”, laughing. This is an old favorite theirs, from early times. Debbie Wasserman dances wildly. Bentwaithe joins her. Something is happening between thos two. Then, John can’t help it, he wants to dance. (CONTINUED)
He takes Georgette’s hand and they dance along with all t other tipsy academics. Georgette is radiant. They seem so happy and free.
John and Georgette are sitting together on the couch by t fire, drinking cognac. They are almost the only ones here There is a striking intimacy between them.
I’ve written myself so far up my own ass I can’t see my way out. The whole story bores me to death.
So stop writing it.

I feel like if I don’t produce some kind of masterpiece, Maggie will give up on me. That book is a big part of what made her fall for me. But, Georgette. If I have learned one thing in the last three years...it’s that I’m not a novelist!
If she truly loves you... she’1ll love you whether you are a novelist or a garbage collector. A long pause as he looks at her.

You did, didn’t you. You loved me that way. She says nothing. A moment between them. Then, a little O World shrug from Georgette. He looks at her. Falling for The lights come on. They blink in the glare. Al Benthwaite walks in at the far end of the room. (CONTINUED)
They've opened the airport! We can go home tomorrow! Debbie Wasserman hoots off-screen. John and Georgette sit saddened by the news.
I better go pack... She leaves him to think. INT. QUEBEC HOTEL - GEORGETTE’S ROOM - NIGHT 84 Georgette is packing. The lights are on. There is a knock It’s John.
I don’t want to go back.
John looks up at her and it’s clear that he loves her.
I don’t want to leave you.
(ushering him in) John...
I want you so badly. I can’t think about anything else. It’s like it never ended, like the past three years never happened. Or that I’m hallucinating.
But they did happen. It all happened.
I know. I know!
We have to stay real. The snow is melting. She is powerfully drawn to him -- and yet -- (CONTINUED)
GEORGETTE (CONT’D) John.
There’s something you should know.
What is it? Georgette pauses, uncertain if she should break the mood spilling the beans about Maggie’s offer. She sits beside looking at him.
She comes closer and closer... and...they kiss and fall o of frame.

Maggie waits, lying on the bed, wondering if the plan is working... INT. QUEBEC HOTEL - DINING AREA —- MORNING 85 Meanwhile, John is tearing into his eggs while reading a by Mick Taussig called, “What Color is the Sacred?” Georg joins him, looking fragrant in a crisp white shirt.
(to waiter with two pots) Coffee please. The waiter pouring the coffee is the same man that rocked Springsteen last night. John half notices this, then look his ex-wife.
Now what.
You regret it?
We belong to each other. That’s it. (CONTINUED)
Actually, for me, this was a one- night stand. They are both so happy. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) But seriously. I’ve changed. I know I can live without you now. I just don’t want to.
Good.
I would like to read your novel now.
Really?
I know you have a copy because I saw you marking one up. John reaches into his backpack and pulls out a manuscript.
Be careful what you wish for.
Maggie is sitting on her bed, waiting. Waiting. She hears John’s keys in the door. Fear in her
Hi.
Hi. He leans in and kisses her swiftly.
Where’s Lily?
Felicia wanted to take her to that dance class. 87. 85 massive 86 belly. (CONTINUED)
John sits on the bed.
How did your talk go?
Fine, I think. Well attended. I got a few laughs.
Was it okay with Georgette?
She eventually defrosted.
Good. John can’t bear the pressure of the lie.
I should tell you something.
Okay... 88. 86 She sits waiting, her arms clamped around her legs. He si down on the bed again, crushed by guilt, barely able to g the words out.
You know we were snowed in?
I know.
So Georgette and I were thrown together for two whole days. And there was this... atmosphere of -- I don’t know, it was very strange. I found myself... unearthing things... old stuff...
Good stuff or bad stuff?
I don’t know. Emotional. Nostalgic - The same stuff.
The same as what? (CONTINUED)
Yes. Fuck. I’m so sorry.
What happened?
Georgette and I slept together. A long pause. This victory hurts. John sits, his head drooping. Maggie begins to cry. Even this was her idea, it hurts.
Georgette was right.
What do you mean?
We should’ve just been an affair. You were having a rough spot in your marriage and I came along and...
But then we wouldn’t have had Lily.
That’s right.
(genuinely torn) It was real between us... all real. When I met you, I was lost. I was a fucking mess. I was so insecure and you...you saved me. You rescued me. I’m sorry. I don’t know what to do.
You know what to do.
No I don’t!
You go back to Georgette. If you love her.
You think? (CONTINUED)
Maggie nods. She’s very sad, but she knows this is right. John kisses her, then pulls away. He is, it seems, in lov with two women at this moment.
Oh, shit. I don’t know what to do. They sit together.

EXT. GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT - LATE AFTERNOON A87 Establishing shot. INT. GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT —- LATE AFTERNOON 88 Georgette, John, Justine, and Paul have dinner. Paul is g on about something that happened at school. Justine is staring at John.
(not hostile, just curious) What are you doing here?
I accidentally ran into your mom at school cause we each thought it was our day to pick up Paul--
Yeah, that was so funny!
And then your Mom graciously invited me over to dinner.
You guys should learn to coordinate your schedules.
There’s no harm in spending time together as a family. (CONTINUED)

Except for -- isn’t that the point of a divorce? That you’re not a family anymore? INT. GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT —- BEDROOM - LATE AFTERNOON 89 We hear John saying goodbye to the kids off-screen. Georg enters the bedroom, drawing John in with her. They fall o the bed and start fooling around, impatient as teenagers. knock on the locked door. They freeze.
Mom?
(calling out) What is it Paul darling?
I’m hungry.
But you just ate!
What can I have?
You can have a plate of saltines, a cheese stick, and an apple. Georgette starts frantically undoing John’s belt buckle.
Can you cut up the apple?
Ask Justine.
She’s busy. (pause) Mom? John jumps off the bed.
(whispering, cinching his belt) This is ridiculous. I have to go. (CONTINUED)
Where will you stay?

I don’t know. I’1l just call some friends--try to avoid a hotel. We've got to give them time to adjust. They kiss. She slips out the door. John waits till she is gone a while, just stands there stock-still.

(os) All right, Paul, here I come to cut up your apple! EXT. GEORGETTE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 90 John making calls, leaving a few messages with various friends he could stay with for the night. Jump cuts as he leaves messages. Then, finally:
Felicia! Thank God you're home...ah, not so good. INT. TONY AND FELICIA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 91 Felicia and John have been talking for a while. Felicia i knitting.
So she already told you guys? She called you?
She called me. I don’t know about Tony, he’s been out all day.
What’d she say? Is she going to be okay?
You know Maggie. She’s been taking care of herself all her life. I mean, she’s emotional--
This whole thing feels so unreal. (CONTINUED)
I know. I think it’s better to be honest. When you can.
I’m just so surprised!
I know. I mean, I can imagine. A fumbling at the lock. Singing. It’s Tony, in a rumpled suit. Three sheets to the wind.
John! Aren't you in Canada?
No. He’s here. Tony looks at Felicia. She glares at him to keep silent.
So you won your case?
We trounced them.
What was it about?
Tainted pudding.
A lawsuit?
What else? Lawsuits keep my wife in post-modern choreography, and me in self-loathing. A good deal all round.
If you’re going to be in that kind of mood you should just go to bed. Tony is fumbling around in a kitchen cabinet.
I’m craving one little nip of that vanilla whiskey you so lovingly gave me for Christmas, Fi. (CONTINUED)
Looks like you’ve had enough of something. Tony holds up a bottle. Talks to John.
This stuff is like liquid crack. Have some?
Just a finger. Thanks. Tony sits down and grimaces in pain.
Aargh.
What is it?
I sat on my balls.
I think you should have your balls hemmed. Like that actor -- what’s his name?
Are you serious?
Apparently it’s just a few stitches, and -- boop! A ball lift.
(adjusting his seat) So. John. Any news? John looks at Felicia, wondering how much Tony knows.
You haven't spoken to Maggie?
I've been knee-deep in pudding all day.
John and Maggie are... (CONTINUED)
John sits 95.
We...
He and Georgette...
(unthinking, drunk) You mean it worked?!
What worked?
(a desperate attempt to recover) Who said that drinks are like tits - - one is too few, three too many?
What worked? What are you talking about?
(looking sick, pushes his drink away) I’m not really much of a drinker.
No. You’re not. immobile as the terrible logic accrues in him.
So this is what Georgette kept almost telling me. Oh, Jesus. Tony and Felicia go into a frenzy of lame denial.
She might have been trying to tell you--
You guys set me up?
No!
No!
The elevated train snakes across the tracks above the sto front.
John walks into the room and turns on the light, starts taking his clothes out of the drawers. Maggie wakes up.
John?
Was it a test?
To see if I really was in love with Georgette, as you apparently suspected? A pause. Maggie feels a little frightened.
You happy now?
Happy isn’t the right word.
I don’t even know what to say. I’m speechless.
We were going to break up. I hada feeling you were still in love with Georgette. And you were, as it turns out.
What about Lily? My daughter. Where does she fit into this plan of yours?
If we’re going to break up it’s -- better to do it soon, for her sake. So that’s all she remembers. (CONTINUED)
John flips.
But I didn’t want to break up! Because, among other things, I was committed to you and we had a child together.
Not because you wanted to be with me.

(on a wave of his own thoughts--packing all the while) So this is the fate you’ve picked out for me -- to just ricochet around the tri-state area, ruining one family after another? I don’t accept that. I didn’t choose this. I can’t believe I let you make me feel so -- so guilty about betraying you and wrecking our marriage, when you masterminded this whole thing, manipulated me into falling for my ex-wife, colluded with her to get me invited to that conference, to make me into some absurd patsy, a pawn in your revolting little narrative. Well guess what? Your puppet is cutting his strings. You can both fuck yourselves.
You and Georgette never really stopped being together the whole time we were married.
What?
I mean, you thought it was over, but it never really was. This is the proof, isn’t it. It’s what you wanted. Be honest.
I think the question really is what do you want? What do you want, Maggie Hardin? (CONTINUED)
I want to live honestly.
Well you’re not off to a very good start.
I don’t want a marriage that’s a lie. I don’t want to tiptoe around our disconnection anymore. You deserve to be with someone who really -- gives herself over to you. I did what I thought was right.
You're very ethical.
You’re the one who slept with someone else.
(laughing in spite of himself) Are you fucking kidding me? John zips up his bag.
By the way, just out of curiosity -- did you ever love me?
Of course I did.
That’s nice.
Where are you going?
I have no idea.
What about the kids?
You and Georgette seem to be such good teammates, strategize with her. (CONTINUED)
He leaves. Maggie stares at the door he’s walked out of. 94 INT. LILY’S ROOM - DAY 94 Maggie walks Lily’s room and lies on the bed. Lily stirs looks over the railing of her bed.
What Mama?
Oh wiglet. I did something really stupid. To fix something else I did that turned out wrong. And I thought it was going to end up wonderful. But I made a big mess.
(finally, something she can relate to) You made a mess? Maggie recovers somewhat. Laughs through her tears.
Yes. But I don’t know how to clean it up.
(lying down again) Use a sponge. Just forget about it. Maggie can’t help smiling.
Maggie is driving with Lily in the back. 96 INT. GEORGETTE’S KITCHEN - DAY 96 Maggie walks in. Georgette is at the table.
He found out.
How? (CONTINUED)
Tony. My best friend. He was drunk. It slipped out. Georgette sits down and takes this in.
It was inevitable. I almost told him myself several times.
The tragic flaw in my plan.
Where is he?
I don’t know. I think he’s just really sick of both of us. Mostly me. A moment of silence.
Georgette. I don’t know what to say. Georgette looks at her, deeply.

You're a funny person. There is something very... pure about you and -- a little bit stupid. Or, no, it’s... a kind of innocence. You’re so -- unconscious. Yet. I can’t help it, I like you. I don’t blame you. I just shouldn’t have allowed him back in my life. I had decided against it, even in Canada. I wasn’t even going to let it happen. It was the snow. It was the cozy, cozy snow. Der Wassa Huchlich. We just... fell for each other again. I wanted my husband back.
I don’t think you have to lose him.
(with a flash of anger) You know what? If he does call you, tell him to screw off. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
Tell him from me.(Seeing Justine enter) Hello darling!
How about if I take all the kids for a few days.
Stop it. Stop trying to take care of everybody.
It's fine. They won’t mind, they’re used to me, right Justine?
Could you please just tell me what’s going on? Both women look at the child. She stares back at them solemnly.
Your Dad and I had a big fight and he’s taking some time.
(to Georgette) Are you and him getting back together?
It’s a complex situation. Justine: a disturbing thought is forming. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Are you sad?
No.
Angry? Justine looks at the women for a beat.
You guys really have no idea what you're doing, do you? Maggie and Georgette stand unable to answer. (CONTINUED)
I mean, there is no plan, is there?

Maggie is driving Georgette, Justine, Paul, and Lily back QUEENS. She looks dolefully at Georgette in the passenger seat. Georgette is staring, catatonic. Now Maggie will be taking care of her, too. INT. QUEENS LOFT - JUSTINE’S ROOM / KITCHEN - NEXT DAY 98 School time!
